newsitem.title: USA: AmEx signals no dividend increase in sight.
newsitem.headline: AmEx signals no dividend increase in sight.

text.p: American Express Co Chairman and Chief Executive Harvey Golub, in response to a shareholder's question at the annual meeting Monday, signaled that the company was unlikely to increase the dividend on its common stock anytime soon.
Golub said investors who wanted cash had the option of selling a portion of their shares.
A company spokesman told a reporter after the meeting that American Express has favored share repurchases over a higher dividend payout in part because of the tax consequences.
In his remarks, Golub said the total return on the company's stock last year exceeded the benchmarks of the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and the S&P financials.
In his prepared remarks, Golub said the company last year continued to build its card business and now had franchise or network arrangements in 20 countries.

In response to a question, Golub said Warren Buffett, who through his companies owned 10.5 percent of the stock, would be welcome on the board but Buffett had conflicts. "We would love to have him on the board," Golub said.
Four shareholder proposals, including one on cumulative voting and another on environmental principles, were defeated. Management had recommended a vote against all four.

Shareholders approved all management nominees for director, certification of outside auditors, and a proposal to amend the certificate of incorporation. The change in the incorporation certificate deletes provisions related to three series of preferred stock that are no longer outstanding.
